latest news.eng_title: Thailand Confirms First Case of Mpox Variant Clade Ib
latest news.summary: Thailand's Department of Disease Control has confirmed the first case of the new mpox variant clade Ib in a 66-year-old patient who arrived from Africa on August 14. The patient had previously tested negative for the less contagious clade 2 variant. According to the Thai authorities, none of the patient's 43 close contacts have shown symptoms so far, and they will continue to monitor their condition for 21 days. Thongchai Keeratihattayakorn, director of the Department of Disease Control, has called for increased control measures, including tracking close contacts. The results will be sent to the WHO and airport controls have been intensified at Suvarnabhumi Airport for passengers from countries with reported cases. The symptoms of mpox are similar to those of smallpox but less severe, and include fever, headache, muscle pain, back pain, lymph node inflammation, chills, and fatigue. A rash begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body, with lesions that can also affect the mucous membranes of the mouth, genitals, conjunctiva, and cornea. The clade 1 and clade 1b variants differ from clade 2, which caused a significant outbreak in Africa in 2022 and generated numerous cases in other areas. The current concern is that clade 1b is more easily transmitted between people and causes more severe symptoms, but the WHO has reassured the public that the mpox outbreak 'is not covid'.
latest news.title: Tailandia confirma el primer caso de Viruela del Mono o mpox

latest news.eng_title: Thailand Confirms First Case of New Mpox Variant in Asia
latest news.summary: Thailand has confirmed its first case of the new mpox variant (clade Ib) in Asia, a 66-year-old European patient who arrived in the country on August 14 from Africa. The patient's laboratory results confirmed that they are infected with the new variant. According to the Thai Department of Disease Control, none of the 43 close contacts of the patient have shown symptoms, such as fever, skin eruptions, and swollen lymph nodes, and they will continue to monitor the patient's condition for 21 days. The confirmation of the case in Thailand is the first in Asia since the global outbreak declared by the World Health Organization (WHO), following the detection of other variants in Pakistan and the Philippines. Thongchai Keeratihattayakorn, the head of the Thai Department of Disease Control, urged to strengthen measures to control the spread of the disease, including through close contact with patients, and stated that the results will be sent to the WHO as per protocol. He also ordered the reinforcement of controls at entry points to the country, particularly at Suvarnabhumi Airport in Bangkok, for passengers arriving from countries where cases have been reported. The WHO declared a public health emergency of international concern on August 14 due to the increase in mpox cases (clade 1 and clade 1b) in Africa, where the virus is circulating intensively. A dozen African countries have reported around 19,000 cases and over 540 deaths since the beginning of 2024, with the current epicenter in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), according to the African public health organization. Sweden confirmed the first case of clade 1b outside of Africa on August 15. The clade 1 and the recent clade 1b are different from the clade 2, which caused a violent outbreak in Africa in 2022 and hundreds of cases in Europe, North America, and other regions. The risk of transmission in Europe is currently low. The Spanish Ministry of Health has recommended maintaining the vaccination strategy only for high-risk groups, such as individuals who engage in high-risk sexual practices or those with occupational risk, and has sufficient stock of doses, including those in the strategic reserve.
latest news.title: Tailandia confirma el primer caso en Asia de la nueva variante

latest news.eng_title: Thailand Confirms First Case of Clade 1 Mpox Variant in Asia

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

latest news.summary: The Ministry of Public Health in Thailand confirmed the first case of the Clade 1 variant of mpox in Asia on August 22. The disease, declared a global health emergency by the World Health Organization (WHO), was diagnosed in a 66-year-old man who traveled to Africa, the continent with the highest number of infections. According to the Thai government, he returned to the country on August 14 and presented fever and other symptoms compatible with mpox the next day, and was hospitalized for treatment. A team of health surveillance counted 43 people who had close contact with the patient, including those who also traveled to Africa, and were advised to observe for symptoms such as fever, skin rash, and swollen lymph nodes over the next 21 days. If any symptoms appear, the Thai Ministry of Public Health recommends seeking medical attention. In a statement, the ministry highlighted that at least six African countries have reported an outbreak of mpox, including the Democratic Republic of Congo, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Kenya, and Côte d'Ivoire. 'Passengers who have been to these countries will have their body temperature taken and be questioned about symptoms observed, especially skin rashes,' the Thai government emphasized. The patient, who is European, has been confirmed to be infected with the more lethal subtype of mpox, responsible for up to 10% of deaths, according to the Thai Department of Disease Control. In contrast, the Clade 2 variant is the most common type. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 99.9% of those infected with this subtype survive.
latest news.title: Tailândia confirma 1° caso de variante da mpox na Ásia

latest news.eng_title: These 7 countries have confirmed mpox cases of new variant
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared mpox a global public health emergency for the second time in two years due to a new variant, clade Ib, which is spreading quickly and little is known about it. The following countries have reported cases of clade Ib mpox: Democratic Republic of Congo (27,000 cases and over 1,100 deaths), Sweden (one confirmed case), Thailand (one confirmed case), Burundi (61 confirmed cases), Kenya (one confirmed case), Rwanda (four confirmed cases), and Uganda (two confirmed cases). The disease transmits through close contact, including sexual. As of August 22, 2024, no deaths have been reported in Kenya, Rwanda, and Uganda, according to WHO data.
latest news.title: These 7 countries have confirmed mpox cases of new variant

latest news.eng_title: Thailand Confirms First Case of New Mpox Variant in Asia
latest news.summary: The Department of Disease Control in Thailand confirmed the first case of the new variant of mpox, a 66-year-old European patient who arrived in the country on August 14. The patient tested negative for the less contagious clade 2 variant. According to the department, none of the 43 close contacts of the patient have shown symptoms such as fever, skin eruptions, and swollen lymph nodes, but their progress will be monitored for 21 days. The confirmation of the clade 1b case in Thailand marks the first of its kind in Asia after the global emergency was declared by the World Health Organization (WHO). Thongchai Keeratihattayakorn, the head of the Department of Disease Control, called for strengthened infection control measures, including close contact with patients, and assured that the results will be sent to the WHO as per protocol. He also ordered the reinforcement of controls at entry points, especially at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport, for passengers from countries with reported cases. The WHO declared a public health emergency of international concern on August 14 due to the increase in mpox infections (clade 1 and clade 1b) in Africa, where the virus is circulating intensively. As of 2024, 12 African countries have accumulated 18,910 mpox cases and 541 deaths, mainly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The clade 1b variant is spreading more easily among people and tends to cause more severe symptoms, although the WHO has sent a message of reassurance, stating that the mpox outbreak 'is not the COVID.'
latest news.title: Tailândia confirma primeiro caso da nova variante de mpox, o primeiro na Ásia

latest news.eng_title: Another country confirms case of new dangerous mpox variant

Organization: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention

latest news.summary: Thailand has confirmed its first case of the new, more dangerous strain of mpox, known as the clade 1 variant. The 66-year-old European man arrived from an unnamed African country on August 14 and has had minimal contact with others since he arrived. The country has introduced testing on arrival for people from 'risk countries' over fears of the spread of the new variant. The clade 1 variant is of concern because it spreads faster and has a higher mortality rate compared to the milder version of the clade 2 outbreak. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the surge of mpox cases in Africa to be an international health emergency. France will donate 100,000 mpox vaccine doses to countries suffering from the emergency, and the United States has said it will donate 50,000 mpox vaccine doses to Democratic Republic of Congo. Health officials in Africa have appealed for the international community not to impose travel bans over the spread of mpox. 'We hear from here and there that you want to apply travel bans … we need solidarity, we need you to provide appropriate support, this vaccine is expensive,' said Jean Kaseya, head of the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention.
latest news.title: Another country confirms case of new dangerous mpox variant

latest news.eng_title: Another country detects suspected case of new dangerous mpox strain
latest news.summary: A suspected case of the new, more dangerous clade 1 mpox strain has been detected in a European traveller in Thailand. The 66-year-old man arrived from an unnamed African country on August 14 and has had minimal contact with others since he arrived. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared mpox a global health emergency, and governments across the globe are on high alert over the spread of the new variant. The clade 1 variant is of concern because it spreads faster and has a higher mortality rate compared to the milder clade 2 variant. The WHO recommends several vaccines for use against mpox, including MVA-BN, LC16, and ACAM2000. France has announced it will donate 100,000 mpox vaccine doses to countries suffering from the emergency, while the US has said it will donate 50,000 doses to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The UN health agency has called for a major increase in vaccine production and said that a vaccination campaign must be a key priority for affected countries.
latest news.title: Another country detects suspected case of new dangerous mpox strain

latest news.eng_title: Could Mpox Become Established in the Indo-Pacific?
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared mpox a public health emergency of international concern due to the rapid spread of the virus and its potential for severe health impacts. The virus has been detected in Sweden, Pakistan, and the Philippines, and it's only a matter of time before cases increase across the Indo-Pacific. The more virulent clade 1b subtype has been detected in Sweden, which is the first time the strain has been detected outside Africa. The WHO is stressing that we know more about this virus and how it spreads than we did about COVID-19. Mpox is an infectious disease caused by the monkeypox virus, which belongs to the orthopoxvirus genus. The virus is spread through human-to-human transmission, respiratory droplets, and fomites, and it can also be transmitted from animals to humans. The epidemiology of mpox has shifted since the outbreak in May 2022, with a marked increase in cases reported among men who have sex with men. The clinical presentation of mpox includes symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and characteristic skin lesions. People with mpox can only transmit the disease when they are showing symptoms. Although mpox is less lethal than smallpox, it still poses significant health risks, particularly to vulnerable populations. The WHO's designation of mpox as a public health emergency underscores the urgency of addressing the disease's potential for rapid spread, particularly in populations with low immunity due to the end of smallpox vaccination programs.
latest news.title: Could Mpox Become Established in the Indo-Pacific?

latest news.source_id: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
latest news.eng_title: FACT SHEET: United States Response to the Clade I Mpox Outbreak in Several African Countries

Event: Public Health Emergency of International Concern

latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern due to the upsurge of clade I mpox cases in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and several other African countries. The Biden-Harris Administration has established an incident response structure to ensure a coordinated response and to take a proactive approach to U.S. domestic preparedness for potential clade I mpox cases. The Administration has been working since December 2023 to prepare domestically and has distributed over one million vials of the JYNNEOS vaccine across the United States. The U.S. government has also provided an additional $55 million in financial support to DRC and other affected countries in the region. The United States is working with other countries, WHO, and international partners to encourage additional donations of vaccines and to address challenges with vaccine delivery. The Administration will continue its whole-of-government response to this growing outbreak, building on lessons learned from the 2022 mpox response. 'Those who have already had clade IIb mpox or who are fully vaccinated against it are expected to be protected against clade I mpox,' according to the CDC. 'At this time, CDC and WHO do not discourage travel to DRC or elsewhere due to the mpox outbreaks,' they added. The U.S. government support for the mpox response builds on longstanding partnerships in global health security and development with DRC and throughout Africa.
latest news.title: FACT SHEET: United States Response to the Clade I Mpox Outbreak in Several African Countries

latest news.eng_title: New mpox clade 1b subvariant is driving outbreak. Here's what to know

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization has declared a global emergency due to an mpox outbreak, formerly known as monkeypox, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and other African countries. The current outbreak is driven by a new subvariant, clade 1b, which has higher rates of transmission and fatalities. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the US is not currently at risk due to the only known mpox cases being of the clade II variety, which is less severe. However, over 1,000 mpox cases have been reported in the US this year, with none caused by the Clade I strain. The unknowns surrounding clade 1b are driving concerns, and more than 17,000 cases and 500 deaths have been reported in 13 African countries this year. Symptoms of mpox include fever, rash, and swollen lymph nodes, and treatment can depend on the infection and symptoms. Prevention is key, and receiving the smallpox vaccination is 85% effective in preventing mpox. 'The current mpox outbreak isn't likely to be anything like the COVID-19 pandemic,' according to the CDC.
latest news.title: New mpox clade 1b subvariant is driving outbreak. Here's what to know

news knowledge.eng_title: US Experts Cautiously Optimistic About mpox Clade I Spread

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control

keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
news knowledge.summary: As concerns grow about a type of mpox spreading in Africa that is believed to cause more severe illnesses, experts have expressed cautious optimism that this branch of the virus will not spread widely in the US or cause significant health impacts. This variant, known as Clade I, led the World Health Organization (WHO) to reclassify mpox as a public health emergency of international concern. Recent outbreaks in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and its spread to Sweden highlight the need for vigilance. Dr. Boghuma Titanji, an infectious disease specialist at Emory University, commented on the expected spread beyond Africa, saying, 'It was only a matter of time before this spread beyond the African continent.' Meanwhile, in the US, no cases of Clade I have been reported, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Several factors may reduce the risk of mpox Clade I spreading widely in the US, including immune defenses from previous vaccinations and infections, as well as better access to healthcare and living standards. Additionally, unlike Africa, where wild animals serve as reservoirs, the US does not have known animal vectors carrying mpox. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has adjusted the risk level for Clade I in Europe from 'very low' to 'low', notes Dr. Pamela Rendi-Wagner, director of the agency. This change reflects the close ties between Europe and Africa, increasing the likelihood of imported cases. Clade I is considered more transmissible and severe than Clade II, which caused the global mpox outbreak that peaked in August 2022. However, experts like Anne Rimoin, an epidemiologist at UCLA, emphasize understanding the risks of Clade I within its context. She noted, 'The data on severity, mortality associated - all that is scarce. There are many questions about the population it's spreading in, its immune response, the transmission route, and the infectious dose.' Recent NIH findings show disparate results for the antiviral TPOXX, which did not significantly reduce the duration of symptoms of Clade I in a trial conducted in the DRC, but did correlate with lower mortality. This suggests that better medical care could reduce mpox mortality. Dr. Jennifer McQuiston, of the CDC, highlighted that the advanced US healthcare system could help reduce deaths. Dr. Dan Barouch, a virologist at Harvard, recognized the low current risk, but urged continued vigilance. He warned, 'The absolute risk in the US is currently low, although we must remain vigilant.' The CDC's proactive measures, including the strategic use of the Jynneos vaccine, appear promising. It is expected that the two doses of the vaccine will protect against Clades I and II.
news knowledge.title: ¿Qué sabemos de la nueva cepa del mpox y que daños puede causar en EEUU?

news knowledge.eng_title: Could the new mpox threat cause significant harm in the U.S.?
news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization has reinstated mpox as a public health emergency of international concern due to a large ongoing outbreak of clade I in the Democratic Republic of Congo. While experts are cautious about the potential spread of clade I in the U.S., they believe that several factors, including immunity from vaccination and previous infection, lack of viral circulation in wild animals, and better healthcare access, will mitigate the risk. Dr. Boghuma Titanji said, 'It was only a matter of time before we saw this extend beyond the African continent.' The CDC has confirmed no reported cases of clade I in the U.S. to date, but experts warn that the absolute risk is currently low and that vigilance is necessary. Dr. Jennifer McQuiston said, 'We are more worried about clade I than we are about clade II.' The CDC continues to urge men with multiple male partners to receive both Jynneos doses, and only an estimated 1 in 4 of those considered at significant risk of mpox in the U.S. have been fully vaccinated.
news knowledge.title: Could the new mpox threat cause significant harm in the U.S.?

news knowledge.eng_title: Mpox 2024 mapped: All the countries where cases of the new strain have been confirmed
news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared a public health emergency due to a new outbreak of mpox, also known as monkeypox, in several African nations. The outbreak has spread to 17,000 cases across Africa, with the WHO stating it is of 'international concern'. A new strain, clade 1, has been identified, primarily spreading through sexual networks, and has been confirmed in Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Sweden, and Pakistan. According to Dr. Tedros, the WHO's director general, 'The emergence of a new clade of mpox, its rapid spread in eastern DRC, and the reporting of cases in several neighbouring countries are very worrying.' The WHO is working with nations worldwide to coordinate accelerated vaccine access and containment measures, requiring an initial sum of 15 million dollars. The US government has provided an additional 17 million USD to support clade I mpox preparedness and response efforts in Central and Eastern Africa.
news knowledge.title: Mpox 2024 mapped: All the countries where cases of the new strain have been confirmed

news knowledge.eng_title: Pakistan confirms first case of Mpox, on traveler returning from the Middle East
news knowledge.summary: Pakistan has confirmed its first case of Mpox in 2024, a day after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern. The patient, a resident of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province, started showing symptoms of Mpox days after returning from a Gulf country, with some reports claiming he came from Saudi Arabia and others from the United Arab Emirates. The patient has mild symptoms, and efforts are underway to trace and test those who have been in contact with him. This development comes at a time when Mpox is spreading rapidly across several African countries, and one case has also been reported in Sweden, making it the first European nation to report the infection in 2024. According to Sweden's Health and Social Affairs Minister Jakob Forssmed, 'We have now also during the afternoon had confirmation that we have one case in Sweden of the more grave type of Mpox, the one called Clade I.'
news knowledge.title: Pakistan confirms first case of Mpox, on traveler returning from the Middle East

news knowledge.source_id: India News, Breaking News, Entertainment News | India.com
news knowledge.eng_title: Sweden Confirms First Case Of Deadly Clade I Variant Of Mpox Strain Circulating In Africa
news knowledge.summary: Sweden has confirmed its first case of the contagious mpox strain, originating from central and eastern Africa. This marks the first known infection of this strain outside the African continent. The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared mpox a global public health emergency, and authorities are closely monitoring the situation to prevent further transmission and ensure public health safety. WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said, 'It's clear that a coordinated international response is essential to stop these outbreaks and save lives.' The WHO has reported a concerning rise in Mpox cases in Africa this year, with over 14,000 cases and 524 fatalities. The international vaccine group Gavi has up to $500 million to spend on sending vaccines to affected countries in Africa, but there may be a delay due to WHO approval. Health experts warn that clade 1 and its variant, clade 1b, can lead to more severe symptoms than clade 2.
news knowledge.title: Sweden Confirms First Case Of Deadly Clade I Variant Of Mpox Strain Circulating In Africa

news knowledge.eng_title: WHO confirms 1st case of new mpox strain outside Africa as outbreak spreads
news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed the first case of a new mpox strain outside of Africa, in Sweden. The person was infected with the clade Ib type of mpox while in Africa and is receiving treatment. Public health experts warn that this could lead to rapid international spread of the disease. According to the WHO, there have been 27,000 cases and over 1,100 deaths in the Democratic Republic of Congo since the outbreak began in January 2023. The global vaccine group Gavi has up to $500 million to spend on getting shots to countries affected by the outbreak. The US and Canadian officials have not identified any cases so far, but the CDC is watching the outbreak closely. Dr. Brian Ferguson said, 'There will likely be more here and in other parts of the world as there are currently no mechanisms in place to stop imported cases of mpox happening.' Lawrence Gostin added, 'The emergence of a case on the European continent could spur rapid international spread of mpox.'
news knowledge.title: WHO confirms 1st case of new mpox strain outside Africa as outbreak spreads

news knowledge.eng_title: WHO confirms first case of mpox outside of Africa as outbreak spreads
news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed the first case of mpox outside of Africa, in Sweden. The person was infected with the clade Ib type of mpox while in Africa and is receiving treatment. The WHO declared the outbreak in Africa a global public health emergency on Wednesday, and officials from the U.S. and Canada have stated that they have not identified any cases so far. Clade Ib is believed to cause a more serious type of mpox than the version that caused a public health emergency in 2022, and the virus is spread by close contact.
news knowledge.title: WHO confirms first case of mpox outside of Africa as outbreak spreads

news knowledge.eng_title: Sweden reports first case of more infectious mpox variant outside Africa
news knowledge.summary: The Public Health Agency of Sweden has confirmed the first case of the more infectious Clade I variant of mpox outside Africa. According to Magnus Gisslen, state epidemiologist, the patient contracted the infection during a visit to Africa where Clade I is spreading. Unlike the previous variant, Clade I is spreading primarily through household contacts and frequently infects children, causing a more severe condition and higher mortality. Sweden is prepared for the diagnosis, treatment, and isolation of Clade I patients, having previously indicated that isolated cases might be expected in the country. 'The news came a day after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared mpox a public health emergency of international concern,' said the Swedish health agency. 'Sweden reported around 300 mpox Clade IIb cases in the previous wave of infection,' the agency added.
news knowledge.title: Sweden reports first case of more infectious mpox variant outside Africa

news knowledge.eng_title: Sweden confirms a case of mpox  --  the first reported infection of the strain outside of Africa
news knowledge.summary: Sweden has confirmed its first case of the more contagious version of mpox, known as Clade I, which is currently circulating in central and eastern Africa. According to Health and Social Affairs Minister Jakob Forssmed, 'We have now also during the afternoon had confirmation that we have one case in Sweden of the more grave type of mpox, the one called Clade I.' The Public Health Agency of Sweden stated that the patient, who spent time in Africa, sought care in Stockholm after being infected with the Clade I strain. This strain is 'likely to be associated with a higher risk of a more severe course of disease and higher mortality,' and is transmissible via routine close contact, such as between household members. This is a notable difference from the Clade II strain, which was transmitted primarily via sexual contact among men who have sex with men during the 2022 outbreak.
news knowledge.title: Sweden confirms a case of mpox  --  the first reported infection of the strain outside of Africa

news knowledge.eng_title: Africa: Mpox Cases Are Soaring in Africa - What Must Be Done to Prevent a Global Pandemic
news knowledge.summary: The Africa Centres for Disease Control has declared the mpox outbreak in Africa a continental public health emergency, with 15,132 confirmed cases since the beginning of 2024. Virologist Cheryl Walter explains that the virus is mutating quickly, with two strains, clade I and clade II, showing significant differences in case fatality rates. Clade I has a case fatality rate of 3-4%, while clade II has a rate of 0.1%. The virus spreads through contact and is disproportionately affecting women and children, particularly in densely populated, low-income areas. Walter emphasizes the need for urgent measures to contain the epidemic, including educating communities on symptoms and action to take, and increasing vaccine availability.
news knowledge.title: Africa: Mpox Cases Are Soaring in Africa - What Must Be Done to Prevent a Global Pandemic
